bibl.title: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, March 3, 1948

div1.p: Siler reports that Kean had to be hospitalized again. He agrees with Kean and Hench that the marker for the room where Walter Reed died should be placed on the outside of the building and not on the inside.

div1.head: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, March 3, 1948
div1.opener:
GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE
OF
TROPICAL AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
INCORPORATED
1835 EYE STREET. NORTHWEST
WASHINGTON 6. D. C.
March 3, 1948
EXECUTIVE OFFICES
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
It was a great regret to me that I failed to see you during your very brief
visit to Washington about ten days ago. I called the Hotel Mayflower early Thursday
morning but you had already left. I then called General Kean who told me he had
heard from you and expected you to come in to see him some time during the day. I
asked that he advise me of your arrival as I would like either to see you or to talk
with you briefly on the telephone. My last use of my telephone that morning was at
about half past eleven. I waited for a call from you or General Kean all the after-
noon, only to find that my telephone had been out of commission. It was repaired
early the next morning and I immediately got in touch with General Kean but he said
that you had already left.

I am delighted that you were able to see General McCoy. I had hoped I might
have the pleasure of taking you around to see him myself. General Kean told me of
your visit with General McCoy. I know that you can get a great deal from him
when you come east in May for the Walter Reed Celebration meeting.

I am sorry to have to report that on Friday, February 20, it was necessary for
General Kean to go into the hospital again. When I went to see him a day or so later
he was getting along very nicely. I hope to see him again today or tomorrow.

I quite agree with you and General Kean that the marker Leslie J. McNair
should be confined to a plaque placed on the outside of the building in which we
know Walter Reed died, this to be worded as indicated by you and General Kean. A
copy of the wording is enclosed herewith. It is quite evident that the room in which
Walter Reed died has been broken up and it would be impracticable to place a plaque
in the general location of the room. I am writing General Truby that it is our
feeling that the plaque should be placed only on the outside of the building and the
wording should be as suggested by you and General Kean.

I have had some correspondence with Mrs. Lyons, of the Hall of Fame, relative
to the unveiling of the bust of Walter Reed. In one of my letter to her, I suggested
that it would be desirable to include in the program a reproduction of the letter
written by Walter Reed to Mrs. Reed on the night of December 31, 1900, of which I
understand you have the original. It also occurred to me that it might be desirable
to include a photograph of the building in which Reed was born, with adequate explan-
ation concerning the temporary nature of Walter Reed's mother's residence in that
building. I have no doubt Mrs. Lyons will write you fully concerning the whole matter.

Thank you so much for your notes from Florida. I hope that you and Mrs. Hench
had the rest you so much needed in Florida and a delightful visit to Cuba. With very
best regards,
div1.closer:
Faithfully yours, J. F. Siler
Col., U.S.A., Retired Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn
